div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

Let's discuss how to
accumulate values in an array.

Suppose you want to
create a dependents report
that looks like this.

It has headings,
dependents and count,

and then down the left-hand
column it lists 0, 1, 2, 3,

4, and 5 dependents, and in
the right-hand column a count

of how many employees have
each number of dependents.

For example, assume 43 of your
employees have zero dependents.

Here's the logic
for the program.

It starts and you
declare the variables
and constants you'll need.

You need dep,
that's

where the user will
enter the number

of dependents the
given employee has.

You'll also create a
six-element array called count,

and each element
will be set to zero.

QUIT is a constant equal to 999.
That's what the user will enter

when there are no more
employee values to be entered.

You'll output enter
dependents or 999 to quit

to prompt the user for the
first number of dependents.

Assume the first employee has 3
dependents, so you'll input a 3.

This value is not equal to
999, so you add 1 to the count

that corresponds to the
number of dependents.

In other words, since
dep is 3,

you take count[3]
and add 1 to it.

Then you prompt the user
to enter the next number

of dependents or quit
if it's time to quit.

And let's just assume the next
employee also has 3 dependents.

This value is not 999, so
you add another 1 to count[3].
count[3]is now 2.

Prompt the user again and assume
the next employee record has
zero dependents.

This isn't the quit value,
so now you take count[0]

and add 1 to it because
the number of dependents
for this employee is zero.
Prompt the user again,

and assume the next
input value is 5.

This is not the quit value,
so you add 1 to count[5].

Prompt the user again and let's
just say the next employee
record also has zero dependents.

This is not the quit value, so
you add another 1 to count[0].
count[0] is now 2.
At this point count[1], count[2],

and count[4] haven't had
anything added to them yet,

but count[0] is 2, count[3]
is 2, and count[5] is 1.

Prompt the user again,
and this time

when you input the user's
dependents lets just say the
value is 999.
The user is ready to quit.

The value is quit, so you
proceed to the finishUp module.

When the finishUp
module starts,

you can output dependents and
count at the top of the paper.
Then set dep to zero.

You're going to use dep
as a subscript to walk

through the array and
display each value.

dep is less than 6, so you
output dep, which is zero,
and count[dep], which is 2.

So zero dependents, there were
2 employees who had that number.

Then you add 1 to
dep, so dep is now 1.

It's still less than
6, so you output 1
and count[1], which is zero.

dep becomes 2. It's less than
6, so you output the next row,

which is 2 dependents,
count[0].
Add 1 to dep, it's now 3.

It's less than 6, so you output
3 and the value of count[3],
which was 2 employees.

Add another 1 to
dep. It's now 4.

It's less than 6, so you
output a 4 and count[4],
the value of which is zero.

dep becomes 5. It's still
less than 6, so you output a 5

and count[5], which
is valued at 1.

dep becomes 6. Now it's not
less than 6, and you're ready

to end this module
and end the program.

You've successfully used an
array to accumulate the number

of dependents for 0
through 5 dependents.
Thanks for watching.
